Name: (D)-LIMONENE
Description: (4R)-limonene is an optically active form of limonene having (4R)-configuration. It has a role as a plant metabolite. It is an enantiomer of a (4S)-limonene.

plant_concentrations.Value: d-Limonene was detected in the volatile emissions of red maple (Acer rubrum), silver maple (Acer saccharinum), paper birch (Betula papyrifera), tulip poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera), narrow leaf cottonwood (Populus angustifolia), big tooth aspen (Populus grandidentata), trembling aspen (Populus tremuloides), blue spruce (Picea pungens), short-leaf pine (Pinus echinata), Ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa), red pine (Pinus resinosa), gray "Digger" pine (Pinus sabiniana), white pine (Pinus strobus), beach pine (Pinus sylvestris), Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris L.), loblolly pine (Pinus teada), Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), sumac (Rhus glabra), juniper bush (Juniperus sp.), fennel (Ferula communis), sunflower (Helianthus annuus) and tomato (Lycopersicon esculetum)(1). Samples were collected during the growing season from 2004 to 2006 in forests in Michigan, North Carolina, Colorado and California(1).

plant_concentrations.References: (1) USDA; Dr. Duke's Phytochemical and Ethnobotanical Databases. Plants with a chosen chemical. Limonene. Washington, DC: US Dept Agric, Agric Res Service. Available from, as of Apr 23, 2015: https://www.ars-grin.gov/duke/
